diagrams.description: Biological Conservation encompasses multiple levels and approaches. Biodiversity levels include genetic diversity (within-species variation, population genetics, evolutionary potential), species diversity (taxonomic richness, endemism, flagship and indicator species), and ecosystem diversity (habitat types, biome representation, functional diversity). Major threats feature habitat destruction (deforestation, urbanization, agricultural expansion), fragmentation (patch isolation, edge effects, connectivity loss), overexploitation (overfishing, poaching, unsustainable harvesting), invasive species (competitive exclusion, predation, disease introduction), pollution (pesticides, plastics, nutrient loading), and climate change (range shifts, phenological mismatches, extreme events). Conservation approaches include in-situ conservation (protected areas like national parks and wildlife reserves, wildlife corridors, marine protected areas, community conservancies), ex-situ conservation (zoos and aquariums, botanical gardens, seed banks, captive breeding programs, cryopreservation), and restoration ecology (habitat restoration, reintroduction programs, rewilding, ecosystem rehabilitation). Conservation tools involve systematic conservation planning (gap analysis, priority setting, Marxan software), population viability analysis (PVA), genetic rescue, environmental DNA (eDNA) monitoring, and remote sensing. International frameworks include IUCN Red List categories, Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), CITES (trade regulations), Ramsar Convention (wetlands), and UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Emerging concepts feature conservation genetics, landscape connectivity modeling, climate-adaptive conservation, nature-based solutions, reconciliation ecology, conservation technology (camera traps, drones, AI species identification), and One Health approaches integrating human, animal, and environmental health.
